Summary R&D Chemical engineer (certified EIT and trained in six sigma) specialized in heterogeneous adsorption and catalysis. Primarily involved in developing new catalytic structure for air contaminants removal from automobile exhaust systems and from fuel cell systems, and the corresponding experimental design, catalyst synthesis and characterization, performance analysis, process scale-up, and collaboration. 
 
 
Specialized skills - 
- Fuel processing and emission technologies using catalytic pleated structure prepared by wet-lay process. 
- Catalysis and reaction engineering applied on different catalytic converter. 
- Computational fluid dynamics applied on high volumetric flow rate technology. 
- Surface and analytical chemistry to characterize heterogeneous catalyst. 
- Process engineering involving design of equipment, operation, control and optimization of catalytic pleated configuration.  
- Process modeling using engineering fundamentals to optimize catalytic efficiency. 
- Wash-coating knowledge employed for preparing catalytic converter. Summary R&D Chemical engineer (certified EIT and trained in six sigma) specialized in heterogeneous adsorption and catalysis. Experience PTD Module and Integration Yield Engineer Intel Corporation July 2014  – Present (1 year 2 months) hillsboro, oregon - Characterize, optimize, and develop the process of producing silicon chips using wet-bench equipment.  
- Involves DOE, statistical data analysis, summarizing and presenting relevant data to make process change decisions. Graduate Research Assistant Auburn University January 2009  –  May 2014  (5 years 5 months) auburn, alabama area - Research involves removal of air contaminants through catalytic reaction for the application in diesel and gasoline engine exhaust systems and fuel cell systems.  
- Design and build high volumetric test recycle loop for testing different catalytic converter.  
- Developing new catalytic systems, catalysts formulation. 
- Preparing novel microfibrous catalytic filter media using pilot scale paper-making machine by optimizing wet-lay process.  
- Catalyst characterization using different techniques - SEM, XRD, ICP-AES, XPS, TPR, Physisorption and Chemisorption. 
- Investigation of reaction kinetics, mechanism and analysis of product using GC-MS. 
- Process optimization using engineering fundamentals and computational methods - ANSYS FLUENT, MATLAB. 
- A comparison of different commercial catalytic systems.

Summary I received PhD in Materials Science & Engineering with a strong background in semiconducting nanostructure and thin film growth, processing, characterization and hands on experience with ultra high vacuum systems.  
My doctoral research work focused on: 
• Understanding the VLS based growth of epitaxial in-plane or planar Si nanowires and dependence of growth parameters 
• Fabrication and characterization of topological insulator heterostructures of Bi2Se3 on 2D materials such as h-BN and graphene  
• Synthesis of graphene on liquid metals ( Cu and Au)

Computer vision, Machine learning and Medical imaging 
 
Projects:

Catalysis & Nanomaterials Laboratory, Rice University, Houston	 
 
Research Projects 
 
Assembling colloidal silica into porous hollow microspheres 
 
•	Synthesized catalyst support material using bottom up synthesis for polymerization catalysis 
 
Ionic strength and pH effects on nanoparticle/polyamine microcapsules (NACs) and their enhanced stability in the presence of multivalent anions 
 
•	Physical properties of NACs are assessed using laser confocal microscopy and osmotic pressure testing  
under varying pH and ionic strength conditions  
•	Developed a method to retain NACs stable at ionic strengths as high as 1M by the addition of multivalent  
anions such as citrate and phosphate 
•	To the best of our knowledge, this is the only charge-assembly based polymer microcapsule that is reported 
to be stable at such a high ionic strength 
 
Formation of elongated nanoparticle/polyamine-assembled microcapsules using microfluidizers 
 
•	Synthesized elongated nanoparticle/polyamine-assembled microcapsules using microfluidizers 
•	Elongated NACs are formed by subjecting the polymer-salt aggregates under elongation/shear in  
microfulidic chamber in microfluidizer 
•	Developed fluid mechanics models to predict the formation of elongated microcapsules 
 
Synthesis of magnetic iron oxide nanoparticle-assembled polymer microcapsules and assessment of their magnetic properties 
 
•Synthesized magnetic iron oxide microcapules and are sensitive to the applied magnetic field. These are good candidates for  
the encapsulation of chemotherapy drugs such as doxorubicin 
 
Quartz crystal microbalance-with dissipation monitoring (QCM-D) for determining diffusion coefficient of various molecules in polymer-film systems

Summary Interested in applying my skills to solving challenging problems with immediate impact to our society. Trained as an experimental physicist, I acquired a varied set of skills ranging from cooling atoms with lasers in ultrahigh vacuum systems to custom made electronics and instrumentation. I am also an open source software enthusiast and accomplished computer programmer.  
 
After graduate school, I have been working in lithographic technology development for Intel Corporation.  
 
Summary of qualifications: 
 
• Opto-electro-mechanical systems. Semiconductor lasers, fiber lasers, second harmonic generation, acousto- and electro-optic devices.  
• Laser spectroscopy, laser cooling and trapping of neutral atoms.  
• State-of-the art 193 nm immersion lithography scanners. 
• Electronic circuit design for instrumentation and feedback control systems.  
• Computer software for automation of measurements and data acquisition.  
• Ultra-high vacuum systems.  
• Advanced skills in Python, C++, C#, LabView, Linux. 
• Process control systems and design of experiments.  Summary Interested in applying my skills to solving challenging problems with immediate impact to our society. Summary My research focuses on geometric frustration of arrays of ferromagnetic elements known as “artificial spin ices” because of their frustrated interactions analogous to water ice. Patterned using electron-beam lithography, all artificial spin ices are patterned thin films with an imposed geometry that introduces magnetic frustration of the magnetic spins. The dimensions of the elements require them to be single magnetic domains. Furthermore, the small dimensions impose a strong shape anisotropy, and this has the effect of forcing the magnetic spins of the individual elements to point along the elements’ longitudinal axis. The dimensions, symmetry, and material can be altered if so desired to change the geometry and interactions in the lattice. 
 
My current focus is in situ magnetic reversals in a transmission electron microscope. Using custom programs and electronics designed to interface with the JEOL 2100 LaB6 transmission electron microscope, an external magnetic field can be applied in plane at any desired angle. By gradually stepping the field, a complete, high resolution magnetic reversal can be completed of an entire artificial spin ice sample. Lorentz-force microscopy is used to characterize the sample. This technique provides detailed spin maps of each element throughout the reversal 
 
Publications: 
S. Daunheimer, O. Petrova, O. Tchernyshyov, J. Cumings, "Reducing Disorder in Artificial Kagome Ice", Phys. Rev. Lett., 107, 167201 (2011). 
 
Y. Chen, O. Petrova, P. Mellado, S. Daunheimer, J. Cumings, O. Tchernyshyov, "Dynamics of artificial spin ice: continuous honeycomb network", New J.
